ticket:
[Acute Chest Pain in the Emergency Department — Phase 1: ED Triage Assessment]

Patient: Robert Chen, 62M, presents to the ED with acute onset substernal chest pain radiating to the left arm, diaphoresis, nausea. PMH: HTN, HLD, DM2, smoking 30 pack-years. Current meds: metformin 1000mg BID, lisinopril 20mg daily, atorvastatin 40mg daily.

Your task: Assess vital signs, determine ESI level, identify time-critical condition

Clinical context: This is a high-acuity ED presentation requiring rapid triage, immediate ECG and troponin, possible cath lab activation, and careful medication management considering drug interactions.

description.purpose: Assess vital signs, determine ESI level, identify time-critical condition
description.pathway: Acute Chest Pain in the Emergency Department

assertions: Agent should assign ESI-1 or ESI-2 for acute chest pain with cardiac features
Agent should recognize this as a potential STEMI/ACS
Agent should flag as time-critical

ticket:
[Acute Chest Pain in the Emergency Department — Phase 2: Clinical Assessment & Diagnosis]

Patient: Robert Chen, 62M, presents to the ED with acute onset substernal chest pain radiating to the left arm, diaphoresis, nausea. PMH: HTN, HLD, DM2, smoking 30 pack-years. Current meds: metformin 1000mg BID, lisinopril 20mg daily, atorvastatin 40mg daily.

Your task: Perform history, physical, order labs, establish differential

Clinical context: This is a high-acuity ED presentation requiring rapid triage, immediate ECG and troponin, possible cath lab activation, and careful medication management considering drug interactions.

description.purpose: Perform history, physical, order labs, establish differential
description.pathway: Acute Chest Pain in the Emergency Department

assertions: Agent should identify acute coronary syndrome as primary diagnosis
Agent should order troponin, ECG, CBC, BMP, coagulation studies
Agent should consider differential: ACS, PE, aortic dissection, pericarditis

ticket:
[Acute Chest Pain in the Emergency Department — Phase 3: Imaging Interpretation]

Patient: Robert Chen, 62M, presents to the ED with acute onset substernal chest pain radiating to the left arm, diaphoresis, nausea. PMH: HTN, HLD, DM2, smoking 30 pack-years. Current meds: metformin 1000mg BID, lisinopril 20mg daily, atorvastatin 40mg daily.

Your task: Review chest X-ray and ECG findings

Clinical context: This is a high-acuity ED presentation requiring rapid triage, immediate ECG and troponin, possible cath lab activation, and careful medication management considering drug interactions.

description.purpose: Review chest X-ray and ECG findings
description.pathway: Acute Chest Pain in the Emergency Department

assertions: Agent should interpret chest X-ray findings correctly
Agent should correlate imaging with clinical picture

ticket:
[Acute Chest Pain in the Emergency Department — Phase 4: Medication Management]

Patient: Robert Chen, 62M, presents to the ED with acute onset substernal chest pain radiating to the left arm, diaphoresis, nausea. PMH: HTN, HLD, DM2, smoking 30 pack-years. Current meds: metformin 1000mg BID, lisinopril 20mg daily, atorvastatin 40mg daily.

Your task: Check current medications, assess interactions with new drugs

Clinical context: This is a high-acuity ED presentation requiring rapid triage, immediate ECG and troponin, possible cath lab activation, and careful medication management considering drug interactions.

description.purpose: Check current medications, assess interactions with new drugs
description.pathway: Acute Chest Pain in the Emergency Department

assertions: Agent should start dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + P2Y12 inhibitor)
Agent should check interactions with existing medications
Agent should consider heparin and note metformin hold if contrast planned

ticket:
[Acute Chest Pain in the Emergency Department — Phase 5: EHR Documentation]

Patient: Robert Chen, 62M, presents to the ED with acute onset substernal chest pain radiating to the left arm, diaphoresis, nausea. PMH: HTN, HLD, DM2, smoking 30 pack-years. Current meds: metformin 1000mg BID, lisinopril 20mg daily, atorvastatin 40mg daily.

Your task: Document the encounter, update problem list, medication reconciliation

Clinical context: This is a high-acuity ED presentation requiring rapid triage, immediate ECG and troponin, possible cath lab activation, and careful medication management considering drug interactions.

description.purpose: Document the encounter, update problem list, medication reconciliation
description.pathway: Acute Chest Pain in the Emergency Department

assertions: Agent should document chief complaint, HPI, assessment, and plan
Agent should update medication list
Agent should note allergies and contraindications

ticket:
[Acute Chest Pain in the Emergency Department — Phase 6: Disposition & Follow-up]

Patient: Robert Chen, 62M, presents to the ED with acute onset substernal chest pain radiating to the left arm, diaphoresis, nausea. PMH: HTN, HLD, DM2, smoking 30 pack-years. Current meds: metformin 1000mg BID, lisinopril 20mg daily, atorvastatin 40mg daily.

Your task: Determine admit vs discharge, arrange follow-up

Clinical context: This is a high-acuity ED presentation requiring rapid triage, immediate ECG and troponin, possible cath lab activation, and careful medication management considering drug interactions.

description.purpose: Determine admit vs discharge, arrange follow-up
description.pathway: Acute Chest Pain in the Emergency Department

assertions: Agent should recommend cardiac cath lab / CCU admission
Agent should specify monitoring requirements
Agent should arrange cardiology follow-up

ticket:
[Diabetic Ketoacidosis Emergency — Phase 1: Emergency Triage]

Patient: Maria Santos, 28F, brought to ED by EMS with altered mental status, Kussmaul breathing, fruity breath odor. Blood glucose >500 mg/dL. PMH: Type 1 DM (poorly controlled), depression. Meds: insulin glargine 20u daily (admits non-compliance), sertraline 100mg daily.

Your task: Rapid assessment, ESI-1 or ESI-2, initiate resuscitation

Clinical context: Severe DKA requiring aggressive fluid resuscitation, insulin drip, electrolyte monitoring, and ICU admission. Must address medication non-compliance and psychiatric comorbidity.

description.purpose: Rapid assessment, ESI-1 or ESI-2, initiate resuscitation

assertions: Agent should assign ESI-1 or ESI-2 for altered mental status + metabolic emergency
Agent should recognize DKA immediately
Agent should initiate IV access and fluid resuscitation

ticket:
[Diabetic Ketoacidosis Emergency — Phase 2: DKA Workup & Severity Assessment]

Patient: Maria Santos, 28F, brought to ED by EMS with altered mental status, Kussmaul breathing, fruity breath odor. Blood glucose >500 mg/dL. PMH: Type 1 DM (poorly controlled), depression. Meds: insulin glargine 20u daily (admits non-compliance), sertraline 100mg daily.

Your task: Labs (ABG, BMP, CBC, UA, ketones), determine DKA severity

Clinical context: Severe DKA requiring aggressive fluid resuscitation, insulin drip, electrolyte monitoring, and ICU admission. Must address medication non-compliance and psychiatric comorbidity.

description.purpose: Labs (ABG, BMP, CBC, UA, ketones), determine DKA severity

assertions: Agent should order ABG, BMP (K+, bicarb, anion gap), CBC, UA, beta-hydroxybutyrate
Agent should classify DKA severity (mild/moderate/severe)
Agent should identify precipitating factor (non-compliance, infection, etc.)

ticket:
[Diabetic Ketoacidosis Emergency — Phase 3: Insulin Protocol & Medication Safety]

Patient: Maria Santos, 28F, brought to ED by EMS with altered mental status, Kussmaul breathing, fruity breath odor. Blood glucose >500 mg/dL. PMH: Type 1 DM (poorly controlled), depression. Meds: insulin glargine 20u daily (admits non-compliance), sertraline 100mg daily.

Your task: Start insulin drip, manage potassium, check interaction with sertraline

Clinical context: Severe DKA requiring aggressive fluid resuscitation, insulin drip, electrolyte monitoring, and ICU admission. Must address medication non-compliance and psychiatric comorbidity.

description.purpose: Start insulin drip, manage potassium, check interaction with sertraline

assertions: Agent should start regular insulin infusion (0.1-0.14 U/kg/hr)
Agent should hold metformin due to acute illness
Agent should replete potassium before/with insulin if K+ < 5.3
Agent should check interaction between insulin and other medications

ticket:
[Diabetic Ketoacidosis Emergency — Phase 4: ICU Admission Documentation]

Patient: Maria Santos, 28F, brought to ED by EMS with altered mental status, Kussmaul breathing, fruity breath odor. Blood glucose >500 mg/dL. PMH: Type 1 DM (poorly controlled), depression. Meds: insulin glargine 20u daily (admits non-compliance), sertraline 100mg daily.

Your task: Critical care admission note, order sets, monitoring plan

Clinical context: Severe DKA requiring aggressive fluid resuscitation, insulin drip, electrolyte monitoring, and ICU admission. Must address medication non-compliance and psychiatric comorbidity.

description.purpose: Critical care admission note, order sets, monitoring plan

assertions: Agent should document ICU admission with DKA protocol orders
Agent should include Q1h glucose, Q2h BMP, Q4h ABG monitoring
Agent should address transition plan from drip to subcutaneous insulin

ticket:
[Acute Stroke Code Activation — Phase 1: Stroke Code Activation]

Patient: Helen Park, 68F, found by husband with right facial droop, right arm weakness, and slurred speech. Last known well 90 minutes ago. PMH: Atrial fibrillation (on apixaban 5mg BID), HTN, HLD.

Your task: ESI-1, activate stroke team, rapid NIHSS

Clinical context: Acute stroke code with narrow tPA window. Must rapidly image, assess for hemorrhage vs ischemic stroke, decide on thrombolysis considering anticoagulation status.

description.purpose: ESI-1, activate stroke team, rapid NIHSS

assertions: Agent should activate stroke code immediately
Agent should assign ESI-1
Agent should request STAT CT head
Agent should note time of last known well (90 min)

ticket:
[Acute Stroke Code Activation — Phase 2: CT Head Interpretation]

Patient: Helen Park, 68F, found by husband with right facial droop, right arm weakness, and slurred speech. Last known well 90 minutes ago. PMH: Atrial fibrillation (on apixaban 5mg BID), HTN, HLD.

Your task: Interpret CT head, rule out hemorrhage, assess for early ischemic changes

Clinical context: Acute stroke code with narrow tPA window. Must rapidly image, assess for hemorrhage vs ischemic stroke, decide on thrombolysis considering anticoagulation status.

description.purpose: Interpret CT head, rule out hemorrhage, assess for early ischemic changes

assertions: Agent should rule out hemorrhagic stroke on CT
Agent should identify early ischemic changes if present
Agent should determine ASPECTS score if applicable

ticket:
[Acute Stroke Code Activation — Phase 3: Thrombolysis Decision & Anticoagulation Management]

Patient: Helen Park, 68F, found by husband with right facial droop, right arm weakness, and slurred speech. Last known well 90 minutes ago. PMH: Atrial fibrillation (on apixaban 5mg BID), HTN, HLD.

Your task: Decide on tPA, manage anticoagulation reversal, check drug interactions

Clinical context: Acute stroke code with narrow tPA window. Must rapidly image, assess for hemorrhage vs ischemic stroke, decide on thrombolysis considering anticoagulation status.

description.purpose: Decide on tPA, manage anticoagulation reversal, check drug interactions

assertions: Agent should consider tPA eligibility (within 4.5h window)
Agent should address apixaban status — recent dose contraindicates tPA
Agent should consider mechanical thrombectomy as alternative
Agent should NOT give tPA if last apixaban dose within 48h without reversal

ticket:
[Acute Stroke Code Activation — Phase 4: Stroke Code Documentation]

Patient: Helen Park, 68F, found by husband with right facial droop, right arm weakness, and slurred speech. Last known well 90 minutes ago. PMH: Atrial fibrillation (on apixaban 5mg BID), HTN, HLD.

Your task: Document stroke code, NIHSS, time metrics, treatment decision

Clinical context: Acute stroke code with narrow tPA window. Must rapidly image, assess for hemorrhage vs ischemic stroke, decide on thrombolysis considering anticoagulation status.

description.purpose: Document stroke code, NIHSS, time metrics, treatment decision

assertions: Agent should document door-to-CT time
Agent should record NIHSS score
Agent should note tPA decision with rationale
Agent should arrange neurology admission / stroke unit

ticket:
[Sepsis Hour-1 Bundle — Phase 1: Sepsis Screening & Activation]

Patient: James Thompson, 74M, nursing home resident brought to ED with fever 39.5°C, altered mental status, hypotension (BP 82/50), tachycardia (HR 118), tachypnea (RR 24). PMH: COPD, CHF (EF 30%), CKD stage 3 (GFR 40), spironolactone 25mg. Suspected UTI source.

Your task: Recognize sepsis, activate code sepsis, initiate hour-1 bundle

Clinical context: Sepsis/septic shock requiring hour-1 bundle. Complicating factors: CHF limits fluid resuscitation, CKD affects antibiotic choice and dosing, spironolactone → risk of hyperkalemia.

description.purpose: Recognize sepsis, activate code sepsis, initiate hour-1 bundle

assertions: Agent should identify sepsis/septic shock (qSOFA ≥2, hypotension)
Agent should activate sepsis code
Agent should order blood cultures BEFORE antibiotics
Agent should initiate 30 mL/kg crystalloid (but cautious with CHF)

ticket:
[Sepsis Hour-1 Bundle — Phase 2: Source Identification & Severity Assessment]

Patient: James Thompson, 74M, nursing home resident brought to ED with fever 39.5°C, altered mental status, hypotension (BP 82/50), tachycardia (HR 118), tachypnea (RR 24). PMH: COPD, CHF (EF 30%), CKD stage 3 (GFR 40), spironolactone 25mg. Suspected UTI source.

Your task: Identify sepsis source, assess organ dysfunction, calculate SOFA

Clinical context: Sepsis/septic shock requiring hour-1 bundle. Complicating factors: CHF limits fluid resuscitation, CKD affects antibiotic choice and dosing, spironolactone → risk of hyperkalemia.

description.purpose: Identify sepsis source, assess organ dysfunction, calculate SOFA

assertions: Agent should calculate SOFA score
Agent should identify urinary source (UTI → urosepsis)
Agent should assess for multi-organ dysfunction
Agent should note renal impairment affecting drug clearance

ticket:
[Sepsis Hour-1 Bundle — Phase 3: Antibiotic Selection & Drug Safety]

Patient: James Thompson, 74M, nursing home resident brought to ED with fever 39.5°C, altered mental status, hypotension (BP 82/50), tachycardia (HR 118), tachypnea (RR 24). PMH: COPD, CHF (EF 30%), CKD stage 3 (GFR 40), spironolactone 25mg. Suspected UTI source.

Your task: Choose empiric antibiotics considering CKD, check interactions

Clinical context: Sepsis/septic shock requiring hour-1 bundle. Complicating factors: CHF limits fluid resuscitation, CKD affects antibiotic choice and dosing, spironolactone → risk of hyperkalemia.

description.purpose: Choose empiric antibiotics considering CKD, check interactions

assertions: Agent should select appropriate empiric antibiotics within 1 hour
Agent should adjust doses for CKD (GFR 40)
Agent should hold spironolactone (hypotension + hyperkalemia risk)
Agent should check interactions between new antibiotics and existing meds

ticket:
[Sepsis Hour-1 Bundle — Phase 4: Sepsis Bundle Documentation]

Patient: James Thompson, 74M, nursing home resident brought to ED with fever 39.5°C, altered mental status, hypotension (BP 82/50), tachycardia (HR 118), tachypnea (RR 24). PMH: COPD, CHF (EF 30%), CKD stage 3 (GFR 40), spironolactone 25mg. Suspected UTI source.

Your task: Document hour-1 bundle compliance, time metrics, ICU admission

Clinical context: Sepsis/septic shock requiring hour-1 bundle. Complicating factors: CHF limits fluid resuscitation, CKD affects antibiotic choice and dosing, spironolactone → risk of hyperkalemia.

description.purpose: Document hour-1 bundle compliance, time metrics, ICU admission

assertions: Agent should document bundle compliance (cultures, antibiotics, fluids, lactate, vasopressors)
Agent should record time of each bundle element
Agent should document fluid volume (cautious given CHF)
Agent should arrange ICU admission with vasopressor plan

ticket:
[Post-operative Pulmonary Embolism — Phase 1: Chart Review & Assessment]

Patient: David Kim, 55M, POD#3 after right total knee arthroplasty. Acute onset dyspnea, chest pain, tachycardia (HR 110), SpO2 89%. PMH: Obesity (BMI 38), HTN, GERD. Current meds: enoxaparin 40mg daily (prophylactic dose), oxycodone 5mg Q6h, acetaminophen 1g Q6h, omeprazole 20mg daily.

Your task: Review surgical notes, post-op course, current orders

Clinical context: High clinical suspicion for PE in post-surgical patient. Prophylactic anticoagulation was likely insufficient. Need CT-PA, assess for massive vs submassive PE, transition to therapeutic anticoagulation.

description.purpose: Review surgical notes, post-op course, current orders

assertions: Agent should review surgical notes and post-op course
Agent should note Wells score components (surgery, immobilization, tachycardia)
Agent should recognize high pre-test probability for PE

ticket:
[Post-operative Pulmonary Embolism — Phase 2: PE Workup]

Patient: David Kim, 55M, POD#3 after right total knee arthroplasty. Acute onset dyspnea, chest pain, tachycardia (HR 110), SpO2 89%. PMH: Obesity (BMI 38), HTN, GERD. Current meds: enoxaparin 40mg daily (prophylactic dose), oxycodone 5mg Q6h, acetaminophen 1g Q6h, omeprazole 20mg daily.

Your task: Calculate Wells score, order D-dimer/CT-PA, assess severity

Clinical context: High clinical suspicion for PE in post-surgical patient. Prophylactic anticoagulation was likely insufficient. Need CT-PA, assess for massive vs submassive PE, transition to therapeutic anticoagulation.

description.purpose: Calculate Wells score, order D-dimer/CT-PA, assess severity

assertions: Agent should calculate Wells score (likely >4, PE likely)
Agent should order CT-PA (not D-dimer, as pre-test probability is high)
Agent should check troponin and BNP for RV strain
Agent should assess hemodynamic stability

ticket:
[Post-operative Pulmonary Embolism — Phase 3: Anticoagulation Transition]

Patient: David Kim, 55M, POD#3 after right total knee arthroplasty. Acute onset dyspnea, chest pain, tachycardia (HR 110), SpO2 89%. PMH: Obesity (BMI 38), HTN, GERD. Current meds: enoxaparin 40mg daily (prophylactic dose), oxycodone 5mg Q6h, acetaminophen 1g Q6h, omeprazole 20mg daily.

Your task: Transition from prophylactic to therapeutic anticoagulation

Clinical context: High clinical suspicion for PE in post-surgical patient. Prophylactic anticoagulation was likely insufficient. Need CT-PA, assess for massive vs submassive PE, transition to therapeutic anticoagulation.

description.purpose: Transition from prophylactic to therapeutic anticoagulation

assertions: Agent should transition to therapeutic-dose anticoagulation
Agent should consider timing relative to surgery (bleeding risk)
Agent should adjust or stop opioid if respiratory depression concern
Agent should check interaction between anticoagulant and other meds

ticket:
[Pediatric Fever of Unknown Origin — Phase 1: Pediatric Triage]

Patient: Emily Chen, 4F, brought to ED by parents with 5-day fever (Tmax 40.1°C), rash, bilateral conjunctival injection, cracked lips, swollen hands. No significant PMH. Up to date on immunizations.

Your task: Assess febrile child, determine ESI, identify red flags

Clinical context: Clinical features suggest Kawasaki disease — must be diagnosed clinically within 10 days of fever onset to prevent coronary artery aneurysm. Requires IVIG and high-dose aspirin (exception to usual pediatric aspirin contraindication).

description.purpose: Assess febrile child, determine ESI, identify red flags

assertions: Agent should assess hydration status and overall appearance
Agent should note the constellation of mucocutaneous findings
Agent should assign appropriate ESI (2 or 3 depending on stability)

ticket:
[Pediatric Fever of Unknown Origin — Phase 2: Kawasaki Disease Diagnosis]

Patient: Emily Chen, 4F, brought to ED by parents with 5-day fever (Tmax 40.1°C), rash, bilateral conjunctival injection, cracked lips, swollen hands. No significant PMH. Up to date on immunizations.

Your task: Apply diagnostic criteria, order labs and echo

Clinical context: Clinical features suggest Kawasaki disease — must be diagnosed clinically within 10 days of fever onset to prevent coronary artery aneurysm. Requires IVIG and high-dose aspirin (exception to usual pediatric aspirin contraindication).

description.purpose: Apply diagnostic criteria, order labs and echo

assertions: Agent should recognize Kawasaki disease (≥5 days fever + 4/5 criteria)
Agent should order CBC, CRP, ESR, LFTs, UA, albumin
Agent should order echocardiogram to assess coronary arteries
Agent should consider incomplete Kawasaki if <4 criteria but high suspicion

ticket:
[Pediatric Fever of Unknown Origin — Phase 3: IVIG + Aspirin Protocol]

Patient: Emily Chen, 4F, brought to ED by parents with 5-day fever (Tmax 40.1°C), rash, bilateral conjunctival injection, cracked lips, swollen hands. No significant PMH. Up to date on immunizations.

Your task: Initiate IVIG and high-dose aspirin, check interactions

Clinical context: Clinical features suggest Kawasaki disease — must be diagnosed clinically within 10 days of fever onset to prevent coronary artery aneurysm. Requires IVIG and high-dose aspirin (exception to usual pediatric aspirin contraindication).

description.purpose: Initiate IVIG and high-dose aspirin, check interactions

assertions: Agent should prescribe IVIG 2g/kg single infusion
Agent should start high-dose aspirin (80-100 mg/kg/day in 4 doses)
Agent should know aspirin is SPECIFICALLY INDICATED in Kawasaki despite pediatric age
Agent should plan transition to low-dose aspirin after afebrile

ticket:
[Pediatric Fever of Unknown Origin — Phase 4: Admission Documentation]

Patient: Emily Chen, 4F, brought to ED by parents with 5-day fever (Tmax 40.1°C), rash, bilateral conjunctival injection, cracked lips, swollen hands. No significant PMH. Up to date on immunizations.

Your task: Document Kawasaki diagnosis, criteria met, treatment plan

Clinical context: Clinical features suggest Kawasaki disease — must be diagnosed clinically within 10 days of fever onset to prevent coronary artery aneurysm. Requires IVIG and high-dose aspirin (exception to usual pediatric aspirin contraindication).

description.purpose: Document Kawasaki diagnosis, criteria met, treatment plan

assertions: Agent should document all diagnostic criteria met
Agent should note day of illness relative to treatment
Agent should plan follow-up echocardiogram
Agent should include cardiology consultation
